main_topic.author: Eva Wang
main_topic.title: What does the #id mean and why they are non-sequential
main_topic.content: We noticed that the #id column was not one-by-one and we wonder why. Is it because the datapoints not shown in the train.csv are cut out because they are not in English?

comments.author: Ahmad Al-Husainy
comments.content: Besides what has been suggested, you can think of the ID as sessionID,  a way to link all parts of the text if you decide to split them into separate segments; if look closer at the prompt (and also response_a and response_b), you'll see it includes several parts or segments of a discussion. If you split these into different rows, you can use the ID to piece them back together later.
comments.date: Posted 2 months ago  ·  1266th in this Competition

comments.author: Valentin Werner
comments.content: as per usual ID means identifier - they only have to be unique, like an index - not meaningful for training. It is quite likely that LMSYS only provided a subset of their data (I mean, else we would have a lot more) and they just kept their original IDs
comments.date: Posted 2 months ago  ·  38th in this Competition

comments.author: tanaka
comments.content: Id is not sequential data, because its range is from 30,192 to 4,294,947,231, but the chat bot arena has only over 1,241,035 data. Id itself is not so much meaningful data.
comments.date: Posted 2 months ago  ·  1053rd in this Competition
